issues.description: The solution implementation of Lecture.java declares attributes using snake_case names (lecture_name, number_of_inscribed_students, number_of_guest_students, number_of_lecturers, number_of_tutors) but the constructor, getters, setters and other methods refer to camelCase names (lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, numberOfGuestStudents, numberOfLecturers, numberOfTutors). This mismatch between declared field names and the names used elsewhere in the same class will cause compilation errors and prevents the solution from reflecting the attribute names shown in the problem statement/UML. Students reading the solution (or trying to follow it) will be confused and will not be able to compile or use the solution as a reference.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the fields in the solution to use the camelCase names expected by the constructor and methods (lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, numberOfGuestStudents, numberOfLecturers, numberOfTutors), or alternatively change all references to use the declared snake_case names consistently. Prefer using the camelCase names to match the UML and conventional Java naming. Ensure all getter/setter/method implementations reference the same field names so the class compiles and aligns with the problem statement.

issues.description: The problem statement's UML and the expected API use camelCase attribute names (lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, numberOfGuestStudents, numberOfLecturers, numberOfTutors). The solution implementation declares the same conceptual attributes using snake_case field names (lecture_name, number_of_inscribed_students, number_of_guest_students, number_of_lecturers, number_of_tutors) but its constructor and accessor methods refer to the camelCase identifiers (e.g. this.lectureName, getNumberOfTutors()). This mismatch means the names for the same conceptual entities differ across artifacts and even within the solution, causing confusion for students mapping problem requirements to code and introducing compile/runtime errors in the provided solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the attribute names consistent with the problem UML (and with the constructor/getter/setter names). Rename the solution's fields to camelCase: lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, numberOfGuestStudents, numberOfLecturers, numberOfTutors. Ensure all references (this.field, getters, setters, constructor assignments, and other methods) use the same camelCase identifiers so students can clearly map the problem description to the code.
